item.title: Real pay continues to fall
item.description: Real pay continues to fall 11 July 2023 Although average total pay (including bonuses) and regular pay (excluding bonuses) continued to rise compared with the previous year, real wages which are adjusted for inflation (price rises) fell over the same period. According to the latest labour market data, average total pay (including bonuses) for UK employees rose by 6.9% in March to May 2023 compared with the same period the previous year. Regular pay (excluding bonuses) rose by 7.3%, which was also seen last month and during the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic. By contrast, real terms total pay (adjusted for inflation) fell by 1.2% and regular pay dropped by 0.8% over the same period. Job vacancies also continued to fall in April to June 2023 by 85,000 to 1.034 million. The estimated number of vacancies fell on the quarter for the 12th consecutive period. The UK employment rate rose again by 0.2 percentage points to 76.0% in March to May 2023, an increase driven mainly by part-time employees. UK unemployment also increased by 0.2 percentage points to 4.0%. The economic inactivity rate (people not in work or looking for work) dropped by 0.4 percentage points, down to 20.8% during March to May 2023. This was largely driven by those who were inactive for other reasons, those looking after family or home, andâ€¯those who areâ€¯retired. Labour disputes led to around 128,000 lost working days in May 2023, fewer than half as many working days as in April 2023, and the lowest number since July 2022. item.title: UK GDP estimated to have fallen by 0.1% in May 2023
item.description: UK GDP estimated to have fallen by 0.1% in May 2023 13 July 2023 Monthly real gross domestic product (GDP) is estimated to have fallen by 0.1% in May 2023, with the production sector being the main contributor. This follows growth of 0.2% in April 2023. Looking at the broader picture, GDP showed no growth in the three months to May 2023 compared with the three months to February 2023. Production output fell by 0.6% in May 2023 after a fall of 0.2% in April 2023, revised up from a fall of 0.3% in the previous publication. This sector was the main contributor to the fall in monthly GDP in May. Services output showed no growth in May 2023, following a growth 0.3% in April 2023. Within the sector the largest increase came from Human health and social work activities, largely driven by an increase of 1.8% in Human health activities after falls in March and April. The construction sector fell by 0.2% in May 2023 following a fall of 0.9% in April 2023, revised down from a fall of 0.6% in the previous publication. item.title: Almost a quarter of businesses experiencing fall in turnover
item.description: Almost a quarter of businesses experiencing fall in turnover 13 July 2023 Almost a quarter (24%) of UK trading businesses reported lower turnover for June 2023 compared with May 2023. In comparison, 15% reported a higher turnover for June 2023, with both figures broadly stable with the proportions reported for May 2023. When trading businesses were asked to look ahead to August, more than half (54%) expect turnover to stay the same, while 15% expect it to increase, down from 19% reported for July 2023. Less than one in six (15%) trading businesses expect to raise the prices of goods or services they sell in August 2023; of these, a quarter (25%) reported energy prices as a reason for considering doing so, 21% reported labour costs and 19% reported raw material prices. The proportion of businesses expecting staff costs to rise over the next three months was 17%, down from 30% reported in the three months to April 2023. A quarter (25%) of businesses in the accommodation and food service activities industry said they expected their staffing costs to increase over the next three months. item.title: Renters more likely to be financially vulnerable
item.description: Renters more likely to be financially vulnerable 14 July 2023 Renters across Britain are nearly five (4.7) times as likely to be financially vulnerable as those who own their home outright. That was higher than people with mortgages, who on average were two (2.0) times as likely as people who own their own homes to be financially vulnerable. People aged 25 to 34 years and disabled adults also had greater odds of being financially vulnerable, according to our survey on the impact of increased cost of living covering the period 8 February to 1 May 2023 . Some 3 in 10 (30%) reported using their savings, according to our latest Public opinions and social trends bulletin for the period 28 June to 9 July 2023. That was up from a quarter (25%) of adults who reported doing this in late April 2023. Around 6 in 10 (60%) adults said that their cost of living had increased compared with a month ago, although this proportion has gradually decreased since early April 2023. When asked about the important issues facing the UK today, people were most likely to cite the cost of living (92%), followed by the NHS (88%), the economy (79%), climate change and the environment (62%) and housing (62%).
